Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Collaborate with other teams to define and design new features
Situation2: Product has scheduled a general brainstorming session next sprint where attendance is optional
Story:
I stood in my kitchen, staring out the window at the row of trash bins lining the curb. Ours was only half-full, but I knew Mrs. Patel next door always waited until the last minute to put hers out, and she’d mentioned her son was away this week. As her neighbor, I felt a tug of responsibility—should I offer to share our bin space so she wouldn’t have to worry about overflow? It seemed like the considerate thing to do, but I hesitated, remembering the awkwardness last time when she seemed reluctant to mix household waste.

My phone buzzed with a calendar reminder: the optional brainstorming session for the new product features was tomorrow, right when I usually take out the trash. As a software developer, I knew how important it was to show up and collaborate, even if it wasn’t mandatory. Product valued input from every team, and I didn’t want to seem disengaged. But if I missed the window to help Mrs. Patel, I’d feel guilty for not being a good neighbor. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I found myself frozen, torn between the roles I was supposed to play.
